title: Textile, "Crocodile", 2007
medium:
Medium: PPS (polyphenylene sulfide), wool
Technique: melt-off, shibori-dyed, and felted
provenance: Purchased from the designer through Gallery Gen in 2007.
creditline: Museum purchase from General Acquisitions Endowment Fund
description: Length of metallic silver and black fabric with a variably puckered surface that resembles the skin of a crocodile.
justification: Crocodile represents Arai’s experimentation with the material polyphenylene sulfide, a highly flame-resistant cloth. The textile is composed of not only PPS, but also wool, and the surface texture, which looks similar to the skin of a crocodile, is achieved by combining a melt-off technique with shibori and felting. He has been working with PPS for almost twenty years, but it was only in 2004 that he completed his experimentation and filed for a patent, however, the stainless steel color of PPS in Crocodile was developed in 2006.&nbsp;
